name: Wampum
description: Shell beads used as currency by Native Americans; also served as storytelling aids in wampum belts.

name: Glass Beads
description: Used as currency in Africa; known as "slave beads" during European trade.

name: Chinese Renminbi
description: China's official currency; "renminbi" means "people's currency."

name: Euro
description: Shared currency of 19 European countries; no single country controls its issuance.

name: Aggry Beads
description: Mysterious glass beads treasured in West Africa; their true origins remain a subject of debate.

name: Gold
description: Precious metal valued for beauty and rarity; nearly all of the gold ever mined still exists today.

name: Silver
description: Once more widely used than gold for coins; has natural antibacterial properties.

name: Monero
description: Privacy-focused cryptocurrency; transactions are designed to be untraceable and unlinkable.

name: Cowry
description: Shell money widely used in Africa and Asia; inspired the shape of the Chinese character for money.

name: Rai Stones
description: Massive stone discs used as currency on Yap Island; ownership recorded orally, sometimes without moving the stones.

name: Grain
description: Staple food and early currency; storage of grain led to the development of writing and accounting.

name: British Pound
description: Oldest currency still in use; the term "pound sterling" originally referred to the weight of silver.

name: Denarius
description: Standard Roman silver coin; its name is the origin of the "d" in pre-decimal British currency (e.g., £sd).

name: Bitcoin
description: First decentralized cryptocurrency; the identity of its creator, Satoshi Nakamoto, remains unknown.

name: Teeth
description: Used as currency and ornamentation; animal teeth symbolized wealth and status in some cultures.

name: Tobacco
description: Colonial Virginia's main export and currency; tobacco leaves were even used to pay taxes and fines.

name: Japanese Yen
description: Named "yen" meaning "circle" or "round object"; adopted the gold standard in the Meiji Restoration.

name: Copper
description: Common coin metal; the Statue of Liberty contains over 80 tons of copper.

name: Reichsmark
description: German currency during the Weimar Republic and Nazi era; hyperinflation of earlier marks led to its creation.

name: Salt Bars (Amole)
description: Salt bars used as money in Ethiopia; "amole" bars were also a crucial trading commodity in East Africa.

name: Florin
description: Gold coin from Florence; standardized weight influenced international trade.

name: Cacao
description: Cacao beans used as money by Aztecs; counterfeiters would empty shells and refill them with mud.

name: Ethereum
description: Blockchain platform enabling decentralized applications; introduced the concept of "smart contracts."

name: United States Dollar
description: World's primary reserve currency; "In God We Trust" was added to coins during the Civil War.

name: Cattle
description: Early measure of wealth; the term "pecuniary" comes from Latin "pecunia," meaning "cattle."

name: Jewelry
description: Both ornament and store of value; some ancient pieces were used as amulets or held spiritual significance.

name: Tally Sticks
description: Wooden sticks used in medieval England to record debts; their burning in 1834 accidentally set fire to the Houses of Parliament.

name: Obsidian Blades
description: Sharp volcanic glass used for tools and trade; prized for its cutting ability and symbolic value.

name: Byzantine Solidus
description: Highly stable gold coin of the Byzantine Empire; remained unchanged in purity for centuries.

name: Greek Drachma
description: Ancient currency of Greece; name means 'a handful,' referring to a bundle of metal rods.

name: Roman Aureus
description: Gold coin used in the Roman Empire; its high value limited everyday use.

name: Katanga Crosses
description: Large copper crosses used as currency in Central Africa; sometimes as big as 50 cm across.

name: Chinese Knife Money
description: Bronze or copper knife-shaped coins; early form of Chinese currency.

name: Whiskey
description: Used as currency in colonial America; led to the Whiskey Rebellion over taxation.

name: Cigarettes
description: Used as currency in prisons and during wartime shortages; represent informal economies.

name: Mobile Phone Airtime Credits
description: Used as digital currency in parts of Africa; can be transferred via SMS without bank accounts.

name: Swiss Franc
description: Known for stability; Switzerland is one of the last countries to issue notes of 1,000 units.

name: Canadian Dollar
description: Features unique polymer banknotes; nicknamed 'loonie' after the loon bird on the one-dollar coin.

name: Australian Dollar
description: First country to have full series of polymer banknotes; features see-through windows.

name: Russian Ruble
description: Second oldest national currency after the pound sterling; 'ruble' means 'to chop,' referring to silver bars.

name: Indian Rupee
description: Issued in 15 languages; the symbol ₹ combines Devanagari 'ra' and Roman 'R'.

name: Brazilian Real
description: Introduced to stabilize Brazil's economy; 'real' means 'royal' in Portuguese.

name: South African Rand
description: Named after the Witwatersrand, the ridge where most of South Africa's gold deposits were found.

name: Kenyan Shilling
description: Features images of Kenya's founding father; used widely in East Africa.

name: Indonesian Rupiah
description: High denomination notes due to inflation; 'rupiah' derived from Indian 'rupee.'

name: Vietnamese Dong
description: One of the world's lowest-valued currencies; 'dong' means 'copper.'

name: Ithaca HOURS
description: Local currency in Ithaca, New York; based on the time-trading concept, one HOUR equals one hour of labor.

name: WIR Currency
description: Complementary currency in Switzerland; used in a barter network to stabilize the economy.

name: Liberty Dollar
description: Private currency in the USA; operations ceased after a raid by the FBI in 2007.

name: Stone Axe Blades
description: Used as currency in Papua New Guinea; valued for utility and as a status symbol.

name: Manilla
description: Brass or copper bracelets used as money in West Africa; played a role in the slave trade.

name: Pearls
description: Prized as jewelry and currency; natural pearls are very rare, only about 1 in 10,000 wild oysters.

name: Roman Sestertius
description: Bronze coin used in ancient Rome; large size made it ideal for portraiture and propaganda.

name: Iron Tools
description: Used as currency in various cultures; utility items like hoes and spears doubled as money.

name: Feathers
description: Valued in South America and Oceania; rare bird feathers symbolized wealth and power.

name: Emeralds
description: Precious gemstones used as currency and in trade; the Incas held them in high esteem.

name: Giant Stone Rings
description: Massive stone currencies similar to Rai Stones; used in other Micronesian islands.

name: LETS (Local Exchange Trading Systems)
description: Community-based barter networks; credits used for exchanging goods and services locally.

name: Salt
description: Known as 'white gold' in ancient times; Roman soldiers were sometimes paid in salt, leading to the word 'salary.'
